Issues.Title: Make centered buttons have equal margin
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->
<!-- DO NOT REBUILD THE CSS OUTPUT IN YOUR PR -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is a **bugfix**.

### Proposed solution
#### Issue
When you have long buttons within **.buttons** and **.is-centered** and a button moves to a lower line the alignment of each button is off.
#### Solution
Add equal margin to both sides of the button.

### Tradeoffs
We are using button margin value of **0.5rem** (**0.25rem** each side for **.is-centered**) that value could change so it might be beneficial to use a variable here instead.

### Testing Done
I tested this with the following cases:
* **.is-fullwidth** on the buttons
* buttons with **icons**
* **.buttons** with and without **.is-centered**

Everything seemed to work okay. 
#### Before:
![bulmabeforefix](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22060392/53293407-e4852b00-3798-11e9-9f91-b4bc0f45c82f.PNG)
#### After:
![bulmaafterfix](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22060392/53293454-6ffebc00-3799-11e9-9015-531127d233fb.PNG)
<!-- Thanks! -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Make centered buttons have equal margin" (#2381)

Issues.Title: Feature discussion: object-fit
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

 This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
I'm using Bulma **version** [0.7.4]
<!-- My **browser** is: -->
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**?

### Description

I'm gonna work on it, this is just an RFC.
I want to implement `object-fit` for `.image`.
 It can be supported for more elements (e.g. `video`) as well although edge doesn't support any elements but `img` for now. (it's gonna use chromium soon so that shouldn't be a problem.)

[CANIUSE](https://caniuse.com/#feat=object-fit)

### Suggested Classes

I suggest using `.is-cover` for `object-fit: cover`, `.is-contain`, and `.is-fill` (the last one is the default behavior so I find it unnecessary) .
I also want to support `object-position` that has similar values to `background-position`.
I suggest using `.is-centered`, `.is-top`, `.is-bottom`, `.is-left`, `.is-right` (center is the default behavior)

I'm happy to receive feedback to reach the best possible result.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Feature discussion: object-fit" (#2377)

Issues.Title: fix/update responsive breakpoints in docs
Issues.Body:
This is a bugfix.

The responsive breakpoints in Bulma have changed but the docs have not been updated to reflect those changes.

From initial_variables.sass:

// Responsiveness

// The container horizontal gap, which acts as the offset for breakpoints
$gap: 64px !default
// 960, 1152, and 1344 have been chosen because they are divisible by both 12 and 16
$tablet: 769px !default
// 960px container + 4rem
$desktop: 960px + (2 * $gap) !default
// 1152px container + 4rem
$widescreen: 1152px + (2 * $gap) !default
$widescreen-enabled: true !default
// 1344px container + 4rem
$fullhd: 1344px + (2 * $gap) !default
$fullhd-enabled: true !default

So in the docs:

1024 -> 1088
1216 -> 1280
1408 -> 1472

docs/_data/breakpoints.json has been updated accordingly.

@jgthms a question about the comments in the responsiveness section of initial_variables.sass:

The commented parts say for example
 // 960px container + 4rem
which produces the old value of 1024. This line is not valid sass so it's not the old code. Is it just a reference to the old code or should the 4rem actually be 8rem to match the (2 * $gap) - thus producing the current 1088?

Maybe these comments should just removed because they are confusing and unnecessary.

I would love to include updates to those comments in this PR as well depending on what the recommended course of action is for either updating or removing them.

-- les
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix/update responsive breakpoints in docs" (#2363)

Issues.Title: Safari's input[disabled] text is too faded
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

This is about **Bulma**.

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**.
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.7.2.
My **browser** is: Desktop Safari 11.1.2, iOS Safari 10.3.3.
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**.

### Description

Safari is rendering `disabled` input fields with faded text. 

Instead of the Bulma default `#7a7a7a` (48% luminosity), the input text renders at `#cecece` (81% luminosity).

### Steps to Reproduce

```html
<input disabled value="Some text" />
```

### Expected behavior

Text color would match across browsers.

### Actual behavior

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6340841/52501503-5d7b6480-2b95-11e9-8902-0c965f8ef960.png)


------------

Here's a StackOverflow documenting this issue (not Bulma specific): https://stackoverflow.com/questions/262158/disabled-input-text-color

It looks like one solution is patching [`sass/elements/form.sass`](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/ff8c4c18accf2c0094aa77945b1d2180ac927159/sass/elements/form.sass#L67):

```patch
input
  &[disabled],
  fieldset[disabled] &
+   -webkit-text-fill-color: $input-disabled-color
+   opacity: 1
```

Happy to submit a PR if welcome.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Safari's input[disabled] text is too faded" (#2355)
